Problem:
Consider a series of kinematic equations \\(\\vec{x}(t) = \\vec{x}_0 + \\vec{v}_0t + \\frac{1}{2}\\vec{a}t^2\\) in a physics simulation space, where \\(\\vec{a}\\) is the acceleration vector. Analyze how applying a transformation matrix \\( M \\) that scales and rotates the initial velocity \\(\\vec{v}_0\\) affects the position vector \\(\\vec{x}(t)\\) over time.

If at a certain time \\( t_1 \\), a new transformation matrix \\( N \\) is applied to the velocity \\(\\vec{v}(t_1)\\) as an intervention, will the final position \\(\\vec{x}(T)\\) for T > t_1 be influenced only by the kinematic equations and not by the transformations \\( M \\) or \\( N \\)?
Explanation: The introduction of the transformation matrix \\( N \\) at time \\( t_1 \\) modifies the velocity at that instance and therefore alters the trajectory from \\( t_1 \\) to \\( T \\). Both \\( M \\) and \\( N \\) play significant roles in determining the final position \\(\\vec{x}(T)\\), combined with the natural evolution dictated by the kinematic equations.

causal_map_integration: Applying transformation matrix M scales and rotates the initial velocity v0, resulting in v'(t1). Applying transformation matrix N at time t1 scales and rotates the current velocity v(t1), resulting in v''(t1). The position x(t) evolves from v0 according to the kinematic equation until t1, then continues evolving from v''(t1) according to the same equation until T. Thus, the final position x(T) is influenced by both M and N.
